Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Age/Sex: 39-year-old Male
Medical Record Number: [Insert Number]

Admission Diagnosis: Unspecified respiratory tract infection
Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved respiratory tract infection

Hospital Course: The patient was hospitalized due to persistent fever and dry cough for 2 weeks, leading to reduced general health condition. On admission, the patient required 4 L/min of oxygen due to rapid shallow breathing at rest and severe breathlessness during minor physical activity. The initial physical therapy focused on educating the patient on dyspnea-relieving positions, mobilization techniques, and deep-breathing exercises. However, with time, the patient's anxiety-induced dyspnea became an issue, leading to the modification of therapy to relieve his dyspnea.

The patient positively responded to the therapy, evidenced by a reduction in respiratory rate from 30 to 22 breaths/min and an increase in oxygen saturation from 92% to 96% on 4 L/min oxygen. Over the next few days, his dyspnea and anxiety started to alleviate gradually, and the patient regained his self-confidence. The therapy was eventually shifted to walking and strength training, and the patient was able to walk for 350m without a walking aid or supplemental oxygen before discharge.

Hospital Outcome: The patient was discharged home in an improved condition, with resolved respiratory tract infection, showing no need for further hospitalization. The patient was advised to follow-up with his regular healthcare professional for further monitoring and management of his health status.

Discharge Medications: None

Follow-up: The patient was advised to follow-up with his regular healthcare professional regarding further monitoring and management of his health status. 

Impression: Resolved respiratory tract infection with successful physical therapy for dyspnea relief and anxiety reduction. The patient responded well to therapy and regained his self-confidence, able to walk independently before discharge.

Diagnosis: Anti-proteinase 3 (anti-PR3)-associated ANCA glomerulonephritis

Clinical Course: The patient, a 58-year-old Caucasian male, presented with nausea, vomiting, and 30-pound weight loss over the past two months. He reported dark-colored urine and intermittent episodes of hemoptysis after receiving his second dose of the mRNA-1273 (Moderna) vaccine for COVID-19. Laboratory analysis revealed serum creatinine of 4.1 mg/dL, hematuria, and sub-nephrotic proteinuria. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest showed right upper lobe consolidation and moderate bilateral pleural effusion. Renal biopsy confirmed acute, pauci immune, focal necrotizing, and diffuse crescentic glomerulonephritis. The patient was diagnosed with anti-PR3-associated ANCA glomerulonephritis and received intensive immunosuppression treatment with plasma exchange x 5 cycles, intravenous prednisone 1 gram x 3 doses followed by prednisone 60 mg daily, cyclophosphamide x 2 doses, and rituximab x 4 doses. The patient achieved remission after 10 weeks of diagnosis with a resolution of symptoms and improvement in renal function.

Discharge Summary:

Admitting Diagnosis: COVID-19 Pneumonia

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with symptoms of shortness of breath, cough, myalgias, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and fevers. The initial evaluation showed a positive nasopharyngeal swab for SARS-CoV-2, bilateral pneumonia seen on CT chest with contrast, and elevated levels of D-dimer, INR, NT-proBNP, and troponin. The patient was started on ceftriaxone, azithromycin, dexamethasone, and remdesivir.

During the hospitalization, the patient's EKG showed sinus tachycardia and left axis deviation on admission, followed by sinus bradycardia with nonspecific intraventricular conduction delay after three days of remdesivir. On the third day after discontinuing remdesivir, the patient had a transient arrhythmia. Potassium levels were low initially and normalized after repletion on day two of hospital stay. Magnesium levels were normal throughout the hospital stay. The patient responded well to treatment and improving symptoms were noted during the hospitalization.

Final Diagnosis: COVID-19 Pneumonia

Disposition and Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged home in stable condition with instructions to follow up with their primary care physician. The patient was advised to continue the recommended COVID-19 precautions including mask-wearing, hand hygiene, and social distancing. The patient was also advised to follow up with their healthcare provider in case of any worsening symptoms or concerns related to COVID-19.

Follow-Up Care:

Follow-up care was advised with the primary care physician to continue monitoring the patient's COVID-19 symptoms and overall recovery.

Hospital Course: 

The patient, an 84-year-old female with a history of hypertension, presented with weakness, dry cough, and shortness of breath. The patient had received two doses of the COVID vaccine. Nasopharyngeal swab for SARS-CoV-2 RNA was positive. On admission, vital signs were stable, with oxygen saturation at 96% on high-flow nasal cannula. Laboratory assessment was notable for abnormal findings. Chest X-ray and CT showed right pleural effusion, basilar consolidation, and abdominal ascites. Medications including methylprednisolone, piperacillin-tazobactam, remdesivir, and baricitinib were initiated. The patient underwent thoracentesis and paracentesis with partial resolution of the effusion and ascites. Despite initial improvement, the patient developed septic shock, florid renal failure, and was intubated. The patient was deemed to have a guarded prognosis with multiorgan failure. 

Discharge Diagnosis: 

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of septic shock, florid renal failure, multiorgan failure, and underlying COVID-19 infection. 

Hospital Course Summary: 

The patient was admitted with respiratory symptoms and was found to have COVID-19 infection. As part of the workup, thoracentesis and paracentesis were performed to relieve effusions and ascites. Despite initial improvement, the patient developed septic shock and renal failure necessitating intubation. The patient's condition continued to worsen with multiorgan failure. Considering the guarded prognosis, the patient was discharged after stabilization with a focus on comfort measures. 

Hospital Course Timeline: 

- Day 1: Admission with respiratory symptoms and COVID-19 infection. Right pleural effusion, basilar consolidation, and abdominal ascites noted on imaging.
- Day 2: Initiation of methylprednisolone, piperacillin-tazobactam, remdesivir, and baricitinib. Thoracentesis with partial effusion resolution.
- Day 3: Development of septic shock and florid renal failure necessitating intubation.
- Day 4: Paracentesis with partial ascites relief and initiation of renal replacement therapy. Multiorgan failure noted. 
- Day of Discharge: Guarded prognosis with focus on comfort measures.

Hospital Course:
Patient is a 35-year-old male presenting with a foreign body in left ear following trauma to the left parietal area by a fishhook. On examination, the patient had no bleeding, swelling, hematoma or bruises, and vital measurements and systemic review reflected normal findings. Patient received an intramuscular injection of tetanus toxoid adsorbed vaccine and underwent successful removal of the fishhook under local anesthesia. Subsequently, the patient developed a small, non-tender swelling under the ear lobule, which was resolved with antibiotic therapy. Two months after the injury, patient was assessed for a localized small parotid swelling, which was confirmed by imaging to be a post-traumatic scar and granulation tissue involving the superficial part of the left parotid gland.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 35-year-old male presented with trauma to the left parietal area caused by a fishhook, which led to the presence of a foreign body in the left ear. The patient was conscious and oriented, and otherwise had no clinical abnormalities. The foreign body was successfully removed under local anesthesia, but the patient subsequently developed a small swelling under the ear lobule that was resolved with antibiotic therapy. Two months after the injury, the patient was assessed for a localized small parotid swelling, which was found to be a post-traumatic scar and granulation tissue involving the superficial part of the left parotid gland.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 22-year-old male, presented in the emergency department with acute onset of swelling and redness over the right side of the neck and chest wall. He had features of septicemia and blood investigations revealed low hemoglobin, raise leukocyte count, low albumin, raised serum creatinine, serum urea, and low sodium. He was managed in the intensive care unit with ventilator support due to acute respiratory distress syndrome and underwent multiple aggressive debridements of the neck and chest wall due to acute progressive necrotizing fasciitis with multiple organ dysfunction syndromes. After three weeks of anti-tubercular chemotherapy, a split-thickness graft was applied in multiple fractions and the patient was followed up for six months in good clinical condition after discharge.
Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to avoid direct sun exposure and to keep the wound clean and dry. He is also advised to complete the full course of anti-tubercular chemotherapy as prescribed by the treating physician. Follow-up with a primary care provider or specialist is recommended to monitor progress and ensure appropriate wound healing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Age: 11 months
Gender: Female
Breed: Brown
Diagnosis: Bovine viral diarrhea virus persistent infection (BVDV-PI)

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 11-month-old female PI calf, was admitted to the Veterinary Hospital of the Department of Veterinary Medicine of the University of Bari, Italy on 12 April 2021 for diagnostic confirmation of BVDV PI. The calf had been identified in a herd of Apulia region, Italy, that consisted of 99 Alpine Brown cattle, all under the age of 1 year. The patient had undergone virological and bacteriological investigations before arrival, which revealed the presence of BVDV and bovine coronavirus (BCoV). Upon arrival, the patient was hospitalized in the Infectious Diseases Unit and clinically examined two times a day during the entire period of hospitalization. The patient was kept in a separate room with straw bedding, was fed a commercial concentrate twice daily, and had access to haylage and water ad libitum. The facility was closed for other animals and had restricted admission for people. Two days after arrival, the patient showed hyperthermia (39.8 °C), and additional samples were collected to monitor its health status and to assess the presence of concomitant virological/bacteriological infections.

Diagnostic Findings:
The presence of BVDV and BCoV was confirmed in nasal swabs, fecal swabs, and EDTA-treated blood collected from the patient, and BVDV antibodies were detected in serum samples.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any specific treatment for BVDV-PI during hospitalization.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was observed for 60 days, during which stool samples, nasal swabs, serum samples, and EDTA-treated blood were collected weekly until BCoV tests were negative. The patient is currently in the hospital and has not been discharged. Further treatment will be provided, as needed.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 53-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, was admitted to our clinic due to the gradual worsening of his symptoms. He had a long history of atrial fibrillation and cardiovascular risk factors, including high blood pressure, which was well-controlled with ACE inhibitors. He had been receiving oral anticoagulation therapy with dabigatran and antiarrhythmic therapy for the past few years, but his arrhythmic episodes persisted and required multiple admissions to the emergency room. After a thorough assessment, we proposed atrial fibrillation ablation to the patient.

PROCEDURE:
We performed bipolar mapping of the right atrium with the ThermoCool SmartTouch SF ablation catheter. The inferior and superior vena cava, and coronary sinus were delineated, and the His potential was tagged in yellow. The interatrial septum was carefully reconstructed, and the Fossa ovalis was precisely defined by setting the color range on the bipolar map to 0.25-0.75 mV and tagging all the fragmented and low voltage signals in light blue. The FO location was further confirmed by ICE and the CartoSound module. We also assessed and reconstructed the structures of the left atrium using ICE and the CartoSound module. A single transseptal puncture was performed using the VIZIGO sheath and transseptal needle. The ThermoCool SmartTouch SF catheter was advanced through the VIZIGO sheath into the left atrium to perform anatomical mapping and PVI, following the CLOSE protocol. Ablations were performed with good contact and stability, leading to fast and effective PVI. The entire procedure lasted 100 minutes, and there were no complications.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:
At discharge, the patient had no more symptoms and did not report any arrhythmic recurrences. He was not taking any antiarrhythmic drugs and was on apixaban 5mg twice daily and ACE inhibitor drug for blood pressure control.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient was followed up 3 months after the procedure with an outpatient visit and electrocardiographic-Holter monitoring, which did not register any AF episode. After a 9 months follow-up, the patient presented no more symptoms, has not had any recurrences of AF, and was compliant with his medication.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and sleep apnea syndrome.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to continue with apixaban 5mg twice daily and ACE inhibitor drug for blood pressure control. He was advised to contact us if he experienced any new cardiac symptoms, such as palpitations or shortness of breath. The patient should also schedule a regular follow-up visit with his primary care physician to monitor his blood pressure and cardiac function.

This discharge summary covers only the patient's hospital course and does not include any outside information or additional diagnoses. This discharge summary does not replace medical advice or treatment plans that should be determined by the attending physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 46-year-old male

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to our clinic due to a long history of persistent atrial fibrillation. Upon admission, the patient underwent an echocardiogram that did not show any pathological features. Oral anticoagulation with Dabigatran was started, and after four weeks of therapy, electrical cardioversion was performed with effectiveness in restoring sinus rhythm. An antiarrhythmic therapy with Flecainide 100 mg twice daily was also initiated. During a cardiological visit five years later, it was discovered that the patient had a recurrence of the arrhythmia and mentioned reduction in daily normal activity due to asthenia. An echocardiography exam showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%. AF ablation through pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) was proposed.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Long history of persistent atrial fibrillation
- Echocardiogram did not show any pathological features
- Oral anticoagulation with Dabigatran was started
- Electrical cardioversion was performed with effectiveness in restoring sinus rhythm
- An antiarrhythmic therapy with Flecainide 100 mg twice daily was initiated
- Recurrence of arrhythmia was discovered during a cardiological visit five years later
- Asthenia was reported by the patient
- Echocardiography exam showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%
- AF ablation through PVI was proposed.

PATIENT NAME: [Name Omitted]

AGE: 34

GENDER: Male

DIAGNOSIS: Pigmented lesion with rare mitotic figures and multiple microscopic satellites

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with a bluish nodule, which was slowly growing on his forehead. An excisional biopsy was performed, which revealed a pigmented lesion with rare mitotic figures and multiple microscopic satellites, extending into fat to a depth of at least 4 mm. Sentinel lymph node biopsy was negative for neoplasm.

IMAGING AND LAB RESULTS:

Immunohistochemical stains for Melan-A and HMB-45 were diffusely reactive and -catenin showed non-specific cytoplasmic staining. Ki-67 demonstrated a low proliferative index. Four-color in situ hybridization and fusion analysis for 104 using targeted RNA sequencing related genes did not reveal any gene rearrangements including PRKCA and PRKAR1A. Targeted mutation analysis for over 50 cancer-related genes showed GNA11 c.626A>T p.Q209L oncogenic mutation. Whole-genome DNA methylation profiling and t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) cluster analysis were performed as described above.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient is advised to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and management of the pigmented lesion. Methylation profiling of tumors offers highly efficient and reliable information for classification of tumors and future studies aiming to explore the optimal use of this technique will warrant improved diagnostic and management approaches for pigmented lesions when there is a concern for malignancy.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Pigmented lesion with rare mitotic figures and multiple microscopic satellites.

Clinical Course:
The patient is a 15-year-old male who presented with severe Tourette syndrome and comorbid anxiety and depression. The patient's tic onset occurred at 9 years of age and has worsened over time, leading to coprolalia and near-continuous simple and complex motor tics. Despite multiple medication trials, including escitalopram, benztropine, clonazepam, clonidine, sertraline, haloperidol, risperidone, guanfacine, and aripiprazole, all at maximum dose for more than 4 weeks, the patient did not respond to treatment. Haloperidol treatment was discontinued due to an acute dystonic reaction, which was diagnosed by a pediatric movement disorder specialist.

The patient and his family elected to proceed with implantation of temporary depth electrodes at 12 sites for testing of approximately 4-7 days since the optimal deep brain stimulation (DBS) target for Tourettes syndrome is unknown. The presurgical work-up showed no abnormalities or contraindications to surgical intervention.

After the patient completed the testing, he was discharged on [Date] with a follow-up appointment on [Date]. The patient's discharge plan also included starting a new medication trial and continued mental health counseling. The patient was advised to continue psychotherapy and to follow up with the prescribing physician every 2 weeks to assess response to medication and address any reported side effects.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

1. Admission:
Patient, a 1-year-old girl, was admitted due to recurrent hematemesis.

2. History and Physical Examination:
Patient was diagnosed with IPH and was receiving systemic corticosteroids. She was advised to avoid cow’s milk. Despite that, she had multiple episodes of accidental milk ingestion that caused repetitive pulmonary hemorrhage.

3. Diagnosis:
Patient was diagnosed with Heiner syndrome due to the exacerbation of clinical symptoms after milk exposure.

4. Treatment:
Patient was prescribed corticosteroid therapy and strict milk restriction.

5. Follow-up:
Patient underwent an oral milk provocation test for 5 days 2 years after diagnosis, and she showed no symptoms or signs of hemorrhage.

6. Discharge Condition:
Patient was discharged in stable condition.

SUMMARY:
Patient, a 1-year-old girl with IPH, was diagnosed with Heiner syndrome due to the exacerbation of clinical symptoms after milk exposure. She was treated with corticosteroid therapy and strict milk restriction. A follow-up test showed that she no longer had any symptoms or signs of hemorrhage. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Overview:
The patient was admitted to the ED with a new-onset headache that was refractory to over-the-counter pain relievers. A non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was performed and reported to be normal, and she was discharged with a prescription for Vicodin. Two weeks later, she returned to the ED with a worsened headache and blurred vision. The ophthalmologist on call was consulted, and further examinations were performed.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission to the ED, the patient underwent a physical examination, which was unremarkable. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain was performed, which showed no abnormalities. The patient was prescribed Vicodin and discharged. Two weeks later, she returned to the ED with a worsened headache and blurred vision. The ophthalmologist on call was consulted, and they noted that the patient's visual acuity had decreased. The patient complained of ear pain and eye ache and was instructed to see the ophthalmologist in the morning.

Upon examination in the ophthalmologist's office, the patient's visual acuity had decreased to 20/400 right eye (OD) and 20/25 left eye (OS). Further laboratory evaluations were recommended, including the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and complete blood count, including the platelet count. A temporal artery biopsy was also performed within two weeks.

Diagnosis:
Giant cell arteritis (GCA)

Treatment:
The patient was placed on 40 mg of prednisone and was referred to a rheumatologist. The patient's prednisone dose was slowly tapered, and she was switched to a steroid-sparing agent like methotrexate or tocilizumab (Actemra) as the prednisone was tapered. Monitoring included repeating laboratory values.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged from the hospital and instructed to follow up with the rheumatologist and undergo further laboratory testing.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Giant cell arteritis (GCA)

Reason for Admission:

On ophthalmoscopy, both eyes showed glaucomatous changes, but the left eye was more advanced than the right. In addition, only the left eye exhibited VF changes typical for glaucoma that corresponded ideally with a retinal nerve fiber layer thickness defect in OCT examinations.

Further examination revealed a 4 x 4mm pituitary microadenoma that was found to be contacting the chiasm. While the cause of this condition is unclear, the patient’s condition remained stable throughout his observation with no change in visual field or tumor size.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with unilateral stable glaucoma with coexisting pituitary adenoma.

The patient was given a detailed follow-up plan upon discharge and scheduled for routine follow-up appointments with his ophthalmologist and endocrinologist.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to monitor any changes in vision and immediately report any symptoms to his ophthalmologist. He was also asked to continue monitoring his pituitary microadenoma under the supervision of his endocrinologist.

Referrals/Consultations:
The patient was referred to an endocrinologist for the management of his pituitary microadenoma.

Procedures/Treatments:
The patient underwent left ptosis surgery.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with no complications.

Discharge Summary for 65-Year-Old Female

Reason for admission:
Left eye pallor with consistent VF loss and narrow angle in gonioscopy.

Hospital course:
The patient was referred to our clinic for examination. The initial examination showed BCVA of 1.0 and 0.5+ with correction +4.5 DSph for the right and left eye, respectively. IOP was 15 and 16 mmHg for the right and left eye, respectively. After the examination, MRI scan was conducted which indicated meningioma involving the optic nerve canal which was surgically removed through left craniotomy. The pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of psammomatous meningioma.

Discharge plan:
The patient is stable and being regularly monitored for any signs of relapse. The BCVA two years after surgery remains the same with a correction of +4.5 Dsph and 0.4 for the right and left eye, respectively.

Recommendation:
The patient is advised to follow-up regularly with an ophthalmologist for routine eye examination to ensure there is no recurrence of the same condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of scalp.

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 83-year-old female presented to the emergency department with a large ulcerated and necrotic bulging lesion on her forehead, along with ill-defined, dusky erythematous plaques extending on the parietal and frontal areas of the scalp and the face, and violaceous-darkish nodules. Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy was present on physical examination. The patient had comorbidities including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, diabetes, and ischemic encephalopathy.

Diagnostic workup revealed a full dermal proliferation of irregular anastomosing vascular channels lined by single or double layers of enlarged endothelial cells, with a confirmed immunoreactivity for CD31, CD34 and ERG, leading to a diagnosis of angiosarcoma of the scalp.

Total body computed tomography (CT) showed cervical lymphadenopathy without brain or visceral metastases.

Although radiotherapy and electrochemotherapy were considered, they were not performed due to the patient’s advanced age, comorbidities, and tumor size. The patient's family provided photographic documentation of the lesion evolution. The lesion had emerged four months before admission, as a 2 cm bruise-like patch on the forehead, and had rapidly developed into a large purplish plaque after 1 month, then to the current presentation.

The patient was referred to palliative care and was advised to return to the hospital in case of any emergency. The family was instructed to provide necessary care and support to the patient.

Discharge Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of scalp.

Discharge Condition: Discharged to palliative care.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is discharged to palliative care, with instructions to seek emergency medical attention in case of any discomfort or symptoms. The family has been instructed to provide necessary care and support to the patient.

Final Diagnosis: COVID-19 with Pulmonary Embolism

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution due to worsening dyspnea, chest pain, and desaturation. Her COVID-19 diagnosis was confirmed with a positive RT-PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2. The patient also presented with a massive pulmonary embolism, as evidenced by her CT pulmonary angiography, leading to right ventricular dysfunction. Systemic thrombolysis with r-tPA (alteplase) was administered, leading to improvement in her hemodynamic and ventilatory patterns. Throughout her hospital stay, the patient experienced additional complications including septic shock, respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation support, and severe anemia. The patient had a satisfactory clinical response to treatment with successful extubation and transfer to the general hospital floor.

Medications:
The patient is on an indefinite anticoagulation therapy with a factor-XA inhibitor prescribed at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient was evaluated by the OB-GYN attending physician, who contraindicated the further use of estrogenic hormonal contraceptives.

Instructions:
The patient should continue her anticoagulation therapy and follow up with her OB-GYN for family planning counseling. The patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately if she experiences any recurrence of symptoms.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged from our institution with stable vital signs and satisfactory clinical evolution.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with fever, shortness of breath and cough. Initial assessment showed polypnea, hypoxia, fever, elevated C-Reactive Protein and bilateral middle and lower zone air space opacities on chest X-ray. The patient was started on empirical treatment for community acquired pneumonia and was later transferred to ICU due to aggravated tachypnea, severe hypoxemia and diffuse ground-glass opacities on thoracic-CT scan. The patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jirovecii (P. jirovecii) and was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole plus corticosteroids. The patient required intubation and completed a period of protective IMV. ECMO was initiated due to refractory hypoxemia and was maintained for 40 days, followed by weaning off for 19 days. The pneumomediastinum and bilateral pneumothorax were managed conservatively and showed great improvement on a subsequent CT-scan. ART was started and the patient showed significant myopathy during the hospital stay. After 69 days of ICU stay, the patient was transferred to the ward and later discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 29-year-old male, severely immunosuppressed due to HIV, was admitted to the hospital with fever, cough and shortness of breath. The patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and required ECMO and intubation due to refractory hypoxemia. The patient was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids and showed significant myopathy during the hospital stay. After 69 days of ICU stay, the patient was transferred to the ward and later discharged in a stable condition.

Real-time PCR revealed decreased levels of MYT1L transcript in the patient when compared to his mother and neurotypical controls.

Treatment:
The patient is currently undergoing anticonvulsive treatment with valproic acid, oxcarbazepine, and topiramate.

The patient will be discharged with recommendations to continue anticonvulsive treatment with valproic acid, oxcarbazepine, and topiramate. Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the emergency department with postural instability and dysarthria, which led to a widened support polygon to avoid falling. The patient also reported dyspnea at effort, which occurred 3 days before admission. The initial examination found the patient conscious with a heart rate of 125 b/m and a blood pressure of 135/85 mm Hg. The patient was polypneic and orthopneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths/min, an O2 saturation of 96% on ambient air with bilateral crackles. The patient had a fever measured at 39.5C. Cardiac auscultation revealed a low-pitched diastolic rumble heard at the apex. The neurologic examination revealed an unsteady gait and the patient was unable to perform Romberg's test.

Tests and Procedures:

The ECG showed coarse-mesh atrial fibrillation with an average ventricular rate of 90 cycles per minute. The chest X-ray did not show any abnormalities. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) found rheumatic changes of the mitral valve, including commissural fusion and thickening. Also, the patient had a mobile vegetation measuring 11.7 mm of length, located in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve. The left atrium was dilated at 47 cm2 while size and function of the left ventricle was normal. Pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PASP) was important, and the filling pressures of the left ventricle were elevated. In addition to that, moderate aortic stenosis and regurgitation and mitral regurgitation at grade A were reported. A brain MRI was performed, showing a recent ischemic stroke involving the right peduncular territory associated with chronic lacunar infarcts.

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made based on the modified Duke criteria (1 major clinical criteria +3 minors clinical criteria).

Treatment:

Antibiotic therapy was started combining Vancomycin at 30mg/kg/day for 6 weeks and Gentamicin at 3mg/kg/day for 2 weeks, in addition to intravenous diuretics with a strict control of kalaemia. Enoxaparin was started at a curative dose for the supraventricular arrhythmia. 

Outcome:

Within 4 days, the fever disappeared, and the patient's postural instability and dysarthria were less important than at admission. Routine TTEs showed a regression of the vegetation and a normalization of the left ventricular pressures. The patient was satisfied after the improvement of his clinical condition and was addressed to the cardiovascular surgery department for surgical treatment of his valve disease.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with no complications and was advised to continue follow-up care with his primary care physician.

The lesion was well defined, lobulated, hypodense in nature, and associated with main pancreatic duct dilatation. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) revealed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes. After the complete preoperative workup, the patient underwent surgical exploration. On exploration, there was a large multiloculated cystic lesion extending through gastrocolic omentum, pushing the stomach up and transverse colon downwards with hundreds of cystic spaces containing lymphatic fluid. Cysts were decompressed, and the entire lesion was excised. The anterior surface of the pancreas was forming the base of the lesion. Postoperatively, the patient had continued lymphatic discharge from the abdominal drain, and the patient was discharged with it.

At follow-up after 1 month, a repeat cystourethroscopy was performed which showed fibrosis and narrowing at the site of IOU. A repeat IOU was done. The patient now has a good urinary stream, no complaint of restriction in passage and dilatations have become a smooth affair. The patient has been on 4 monthly dilatation for the past year which have all been smooth and has now been called after 6 months for next follow-up.

The patient was admitted with complaints of swelling in the right inguinoscrotal region associated with repeated thinning of urinary stream and recurrent episodes of burning micturition. The patient was a 70-year-old man who presented with repeated upper abdominal pain and was diagnosed with resectable pancreatic cancer of the pancreatic body. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) suggested that the patient may have a stricture of the CA root, which may have been caused by median arcuate ligament (MAL). Pancreaticoduodenectomy with division of the MAL was scheduled but unexpected bleeding around the CA was observed during surgery. Bleeding could be controlled by simple compression only, and hemostasis by suturing was attempted first. Contrary to expectations, the bleeding intensified, making it difficult to confirm the bleeding point. Therefore, supraceliac aortic cross-clamping (SAC) was performed to manage the bleeding. After performing SAC, the bleeding intensity significantly decreased, and a defect of the adventitia measuring 7 mm in diameter on the CA was confirmed. The defect was repaired, and the patient underwent a distal pancreatectomy to decrease the risk of hepatic infarction. The patient was discharged uneventfully on postoperative day 19.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 77-year-old Japanese woman, para 7, was admitted to our hospital with sudden onset of left lower abdominal pain. Computed tomography (CT) revealed a 7.5-cm long elliptical mass in the left adnexal region that was continuous with the uterus. She was diagnosed with torsion of a left ovarian cyst and underwent surgery.

The patient had a history of left-side breast cancer and underwent total left mastectomy at the age of 67, with no recurrence thereafter. Although she was a carrier of hepatitis C, her liver function and coagulation remained normal, and she was being followed-up without medication. Furthermore, she was taking nifedipine and candesartan cilexetil for hypertension. Her family history and psychosocial history were unremarkable. She also had no history of trauma.

After admission, the hematoma did not enlarge, and the hemoglobin and hematocrit levels did not decrease. After 11 days of bed rest, with no exacerbation of the inflammatory response, lower abdominal pain was relieved, and she was discharged. After discharge, we planned to investigate the cause of her bleeding on an outpatient basis, but 6 days after discharge, she was readmitted to our hospital after relapse of symptoms caused by retroperitoneal bleeding from the same site. The hematoma had grown to a size of 11.7 cm, and an abnormal vascular network was found extending from the left side of the uterus to the left adnexal area. It was suspected to be an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) or arteriovenous fistula (AVF) from the uterine artery to the left ovarian vein (LOV).

Urgent treatment was needed for her repeated bleeding, and vascular embolization therapy was performed simultaneously with angiography. The cause of retroperitoneal bleeding was rupture of the LOV, the distension of which was caused by reflux. We performed embolization of LOV with N-butyl-2-cyanoacrylate and placed a coil centrally to prevent recanalization. The retroperitoneal hematoma gradually shrank and disappeared. At her final visit 2 years later, the hematoma had not recurred.

Hospital Course Summary:

She had a history of left-side breast cancer and hypertension, but her liver function and coagulation remained normal, and there were no significant findings on physical examination. However, she was readmitted to our hospital 6 days after discharge with relapse of symptoms caused by retroperitoneal bleeding from the same site. A Whipple’s procedure was planned initially, but the patient's cardiac arrest during the operation directed the plan to a damage control surgery. From the available data, the patient had a severe case of duodenal ischemia or necrosis after admission with abdominal pain, fever, oral intolerance, nausea, and vomiting. The possible etiologies may have been microvascular ischemia or necrosis.

Renal oncocytoma with symptomatic hematuria leading to giant clot retention in the urinary bladder.

Laparoscopic partial nephrectomy of the right kidney and tumor resection.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 44-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for induction chemotherapy (IC) on day 0 and experienced bone marrow suppression with fever and septic shock on day 10. Broad-spectrum antibacterial and antifungal prophylaxis were used empirically, with little success in controlling the patient's recurrent fever. The patient then experienced hemiplegia and hemiconvulsions on the right limb and was diagnosed with cerebral infarction in the right parietal lobe and small hypodense areas in the left and right parietal lobes. CT scans also showed multiple hyperdense lesions in the patient's lung on day 18. After a positive result for the test of (1,3)- β-D-glucan on day 22, treatment was changed to voriconazole (VRC) and imipenem, but the patient's fever persisted and the lesions in the brain and lung worsened.

On day 25, Rhizomucor miehei infection was shown by metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of peripheral blood (PB) with high relative abundance, and liposome-associated amphotericin B was administered as antifungal therapy. The patient's fever subsided, and his complete blood count (CBC) returned to normal on day 28. Infection with Rhizomucor miehei was also detected by mNGS findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) on day 28 and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) on day 35. Antifungal therapy using liposome-associated amphotericin B was continued until day 55, and the patient's general condition improved, with partial recovery of the right limb function.

After discharge, the patient continued antifungal therapy with amphotericin B and posaconazole for 2 months and received a new chemotherapy for ALL. Follow-up imaging tests showed a significant reduction in the size of the lesions. The antifungal drug regimen was well-tolerated and achieved a remarkable effect. 

Important Findings:

The patient had a series of infections caused by Rhizomucor miehei, which were detected by mNGS findings. The antifungal therapy using liposome-associated amphotericin B was an effective treatment for the patient's condition. The recurrence of fever in febrile neutropenia patients after chemotherapy with cerebral symptoms may be highly indicative of infections in the brain.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged and requested to continue antifungal therapy at a local hospital due to family reasons.

Post-infectious abducens nerve palsy secondary to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

The patient was regularly seen for ophthalmologic follow-ups after discharge.

Thyroid tumor with extensive local organ and tissue invasion, pulmonary metastasis, and relapse.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 75-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease and Enterococcus faecalis bacteremia, was admitted to our hospital for subacute functional decline and encephalopathy. On admission, he had a leukocytosis and bilateral pleural effusions. Imaging and testing revealed left ventricular and right ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild pulmonary hypertension, and no visible valvular vegetations. Thoracentesis of the patient's pleural effusions identified Enterococcus faecalis growth, leading to the performance of a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).

During the TEE procedure performed on hospital day nine, the patient received 70 mg of propofol administered over the first ten minutes of the procedure. The patient's blood pressure dropped precipitously, and he experienced a PEA cardiac arrest. After four rounds of chest compressions and epinephrine administration, the patient achieved ROSC. However, the patient's cardiac rhythm deteriorated into ventricular fibrillation, which required defibrillation and further chest compressions. ROSC was achieved again, and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit.

Upon review of the TEE images, it was noted that the patient's RV was severely dilated with minimal contractile function, and a small pericardial effusion was found. Due to the critical nature of the patient's condition, comfort measures were implemented, and the patient's family opted for transition to end-of-life care. 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been discharged to hospice care. Due to his end-stage renal disease and critical condition, it is not appropriate to provide further medical therapy. Comfort measures and end-of-life care will be provided in this setting. The patient's family has been informed about his condition, and they have agreed to this course of action.

The patient was transferred to the cardiology service and cardiorespiratory examination was within normal limits.

The respiratory viral panel was negative. Clozapine was discontinued, and he was started on metoprolol, colchicine, and ibuprofen to manage impaired LV function and pericarditis. Repeat EKG revealed resolution of ST-elevation and no arrhythmic events on telemetry. The patient was discharged back to the psychiatric hospital with planned cardiology follow-up for echocardiogram and repeat laboratory testing.

DIAGNOSES:
1. Myopericarditis, likely drug-induced
2. Treatment-resistant schizoaffective disorder

The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care provider or cardiology team for further evaluation and management regarding potential cardiac involvement associated with clozapine therapy. Follow-up with primary care provider or cardiology team for echocardiogram and repeat laboratory testing.

Discharge Summary:

History: End-stage renal disease of unknown etiology, hypertension, and high cholesterol. Had undergone a living related kidney transplant with induction therapy consisting of basiliximab and solumedrol. Maintenance therapy was with tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented to the renal transplant clinic complaining of edema that had appeared over the previous three days. He admitted to inadvertently taking less tacrolimus than prescribed for almost one month. On examination, he had periorbital edema and lower extremity edema. Laboratory data showed an increase in creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy was ordered and conducted, revealing evidence of postinfectious glomerulonephritis and minimal residual subendothelial electron dense deposits. Anti-streptolysin O (ASO) was elevated, indicating Streptococcus might have caused the infection.

Treatment:

Prednisone was increased, and the tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil dosages were increased, due to acute kidney injury, proteinuria, and hematuria. Given that his AKI did not appear to be due to rejection, tacrolimus was decreased back to the basal dose of 3 mg twice a day and prednisone was tapered to 10 mg daily. Fluid management was achieved with furosemide. No antibiotics were prescribed. A month later, creatinine had decreased and returned to baseline. Proteinuria and hematuria had completely resolved after three months.

Outcome:

The patient's condition improved significantly, and he was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up care was arranged with a recommendation to continue therapy and undergo regular check-ups.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:
2-year-old boy

Presenting Problem:
Progressive painful and difficult voiding with only few drops of urine after straining, fever, agitation, vomiting, urinary retention, and significant abdominal distension.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent an office-based surgical circumcision which resulted in profound bleeding that was ultimately controlled by deep suturing. However, during the postoperative period, the patient started to experience painful and difficult voiding. After about a week, the patient was referred to a district hospital with fever, agitation, vomiting, urinary retention, and significant abdominal distension. Urgent abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed a large volume of free fluid in the abdomen and pelvis with a small amount of urine in the bladder. Catheterization with a 6-Fr feeding tube failed because it did not pass beyond the subcoronal urethra. The patient underwent an emergency midline laparotomy which revealed a small intraperitoneal bladder rupture at the dome of the bladder. The diagnosis of intraperitoneal bladder rupture with urinary ascites was made, likely caused by near-total urethral obstruction. The rupture site was repaired in two layers, and a suprapubic cystostomy catheter was fixed.

Follow-up:
Two months later, at our center, antegrade voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) was performed via the suprapubic catheter which showed terminal urethral obstruction. A decision was made to explore the area and repair the urethra. An end-to-end urethral anastomosis was performed, and the postoperative period was uneventful. The patient was discharged home with a suprapubic and urethral catheter. The urethral catheter was removed seven days following surgery, and the suprapubic catheter was removed four weeks after surgery following normal urethral voiding and normal ultrasound. A VCUG was performed six weeks after surgery that showed normal bladder and urethra with acceptable voiding per urethra. During a 2.5-year follow-up period, the patient was asymptomatic with normal renal function, ultrasound, and voiding pattern. He had a maximum flow rate of 15.3 ml/sec in uroflowmetry study.

Contributing Factors:
The underlying cause of the rupture was likely due to near-total urethral obstruction.

Outcome:
The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy and urethral anastomosis procedure with no complications. The patient has since been asymptomatic with normal renal function, ultrasound, and voiding pattern.

The 51-year-old male patient was admitted with hypercalcemia, renal failure, and persistent leg and low back pain. On admission, he reported fatigue, bone pain, and polyuria. Physical examination revealed no specific findings of the lymph nodes, head, neck, heart, lung, abdomen, or joints. Laboratory testing revealed corrected serum calcium of 3.39 mmol/L, phosphorus of 0.84 mmol/L, PTH of 540 ng/mL, serum creatinine of 151 μmol/L (after hemodialysis), and hemoglobin of 120 g/L. Urine calcium was 9.2 mmol/24 h. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed complete right bundle branch block and a precordial abnormal ST segment and normal corrected QT (QTc) interval. Ultrasonography revealed a nodule at the left lower pole of the parathyroid gland. Single-photon emission computed tomography results indicated an adenoma of the left lower pole of the parathyroid gland.

Treatment:
Hydration with 3000 mL of fluid per day, furosemide at 40 mg three times per day, cinacalcet at 25 mg per day, and RRT were utilized to reduce serum calcium levels. Slow extended dialysis with low-calcium dialysate (1.25 mmol) at bedside was started using a commercially available continuous RRT device (multiFiltrate, Fresenius Medical Care Deutschland GmbH, Bad Homburg, Germany). Due to no family history of such disease and no medication history of thiazide or lithium, a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism caused by a parathyroid adenoma was made. However, due to the high level of troponin T and changes to the ST segment on an ECG, parathyroidectomy was deferred for multidisciplinary consultation.

Outcome: 
After gradual reduction of serum calcium levels and preparation for parathyroidectomy, the patient underwent parathyroidectomy and an untypical parathyroid adenoma was pathologically confirmed. Postoperatively, PTH dropped to 16.9 ng/L and serum calcium dropped to 2.25 mmol/L. Serum calcium was 2.11 mmol/L and serum creatinine was 173 μmol/L at discharge. The patient reported serum calcium of 2.13 mmol/L and serum creatinine of 112 μmol/L without calcium supplementation at 2 months after discharge.

Hospital Course Summary
The patient was admitted with a 4-month history of fluctuating weakness of the right upper and lower extremities associated with a band-like sensation of the trunk along with bowel and bladder disturbances. Weakness progressed to the left lower extremity causing difficulty in ambulation and eventually became quadriparetic. The patient's condition deteriorated and she developed dysphagia, dysphonia, difficulty breathing, and projectile vomiting.

Initial Assessment
The patient was hemodynamically stable upon admission with no spinal deformities noted. She had lax sphincter tone and hypesthesia was described. The patient was hyper-reflexic on both the upper and lower extremities along with bilateral extensor toe sign.

Diagnostic Tests
Initial work-up included a cranio-spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealing a long expansile contrast-enhancing mass involving the entire spinal cord, from the level of the cervical region to the conus medullaris with extension to the lower medulla oblongata. 

Medical Management
The patient was started on dexamethasone, which provided minimal relief of symptoms. She was referred to the neurosurgery service and was advised for surgery.

Outcome
Unfortunately, on the 20th hospital day, the patient's symptoms progressed to quadriplegia and respiratory failure. She subsequently developed healthcare-associated pneumonia succumbing to septicemia.

Autopsy
On autopsy, all lobes of the lungs were consolidated secondary to pneumonia. There was swelling of the entire spinal cord with white to yellow mucoid material coming out from the central canal. Cut sections showed that the entire spinal cord and caudal medullary region were replaced by mucoid material. Histopathologic examination of the spinal cord revealed a cellular tumor arranged around the central canal of the cord. The cells are generally small, with round to slightly ovoid nuclei. Fibrillary processes were noted in the cytoplasm.

Diagnosis
The patient was diagnosed with holocord oligodendroglioma.

Recommendation
Further genetic characterization of the tumor such as IDH, 1p/19q codeletion, MGMT, EGFR and TP53 mutations were not done because of its unavailability in the institution but its histologic and immunochemical features are consistent with holocord oligodendroglioma.

Medical History:
A six-year-old female boxer dog with a 13-month history of progressive and mildly pruritic skin lesions.

Admission Exam:
Physical examination of the dog revealed no abnormalities. On dermatological examination, nine ulcerated and nonulcerated skin nodules were observed, ranged from 1 to 7 cm in diameter, and distributed mainly over bony prominences of distal extremities and digits of the front legs, left elbow, and right hock. Other skin lesions included footpad hyperkeratosis, crusting, depigmentation, and erosions.

Diagnostic Tests:
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology made from material obtained from nonulcerated skin nodules revealed pyogranulomatous inflammation and numerous mainly extracellular round-shaped organisms, ranging from 20 to 30 μm in diameter, most containing 2 spores of approximately 10 μm in diameter. A culture of FNA material in dermatophyte test medium (DTM) was performed, and smooth, creamy, yeast-like colonies were grown. Histopathology revealed nodular-to-diffuse, pyogranulomatous dermatitis and panniculitis.

Diagnosis:
Cutaneous protothecosis due to Prototheca wickerhamii was confirmed through sequencing of a portion of the 28S rRNA gene following DNA isolation.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with oral fluconazole, which resulted in significant clinical improvement in footpad lesions after one month of administration. However, the progression of skin nodules was not slowed with this treatment regimen. A protocol developed to treat canine cryptococcosis was then applied, which involved subcutaneous infusion of AMB and concurrent administration of itraconazole. Due to nephrotoxicity, AMB was discontinued after seven infusions, and the patient is presently receiving itraconazole alone.

Follow-Up:
Although skin nodules have not shown any improvement with this treatment regimen, footpads remain close to normal.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 30-year old pregnant woman who presented with left lower quadrant discomfort during her second month of pregnancy. A mixed cystic and solid left adnexal mass measuring 8.6 × 6.7 × 8.3 cm was discovered during an ultrasound examination. A left salpingo-oophorectomy was performed early in the second trimester. Grossly, an intact 7.5 cm complex cystic-solid mass with nearly half involved by a friable, tan-yellow tumor with papillary excrescences, some of which were freely floating within the cyst cavity was noted. Histologic sections revealed a struma ovarii with over 50% characterized by the classic features of a well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The periphery of the tumor impinged on the ovarian capsule and vascular structures, but no definitive evidence of invasion was found on the histologic sections reviewed. Ovarian mature cystic teratoma was also present in other areas of the tumor.

The patient’s tumor expressed positive immunohistochemical staining for thyroglobulin (Tg) and thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1), but was negative for BRAF V600E. Serum Tg was found to be elevated after surgical removal of the ovarian mass, which is reasonably expected given the proximity to surgery and the known increase in Tg levels during pregnancy. Thyroid function tests and thyroid ultrasound were normal. Levothyroxine (L-T4) was initiated to suppress thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).

After delivery, the patient underwent total thyroidectomy to permit evaluation for metastatic disease and monitoring for recurrence by Tg levels. Thyroid pathology was benign. Several months after delivery, cessation of lactation and L-T4 withdrawal resulted in an unexpected rise in Tg levels. A concurrent diagnostic I-131 scan was performed with planar and SPECT/CT imaging. The scan revealed focal central neck activity consistent with thyroid remnant and the presence of iodine-avid skeletal metastatic disease involving the left ninth rib, bilateral proximal femurs and sacrum. High-quality SPECT/CT images eliminated the need for separate dedicated CT and bone scan. The patient was treated with TSH suppression resulting in an undetectable Tg level.

Follow-up evaluations demonstrated a stimulated Tg level and negative diagnostic I-131 scan without focal abnormal radioiodine uptake in the neck or skeleton. A 100 mCi I-131 therapeutic challenge was performed to eliminate any microscopic residual disease and more accurately ascertain the treatment response. The post-therapy I-131 scan demonstrated complete resolution of pulmonary metastatic disease. Faint residual foci of activity were demonstrated in the left ninth rib, sacrum, and left proximal femur, consistent with a partial therapeutic response in the skeleton.

The patient continues to do well, being conservatively managed with active clinical and biochemical monitoring during L-T4 suppression therapy.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 79-year-old woman, was admitted for evaluation of abnormal murmur. She presented with a 3-months history of worsening shortness of breath and orthopnea. Physical examination revealed a soft continuous murmur at the left upper chest with basal crackles in both lungs. Chest radiography showed mild cardiomegaly with mild pulmonary congestion. The ECG showed regular sinus rhythm without evidence of ischemia or prior myocardial infarction.
Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a mildly dilated LV with markedly dilated left atrium. The LV ejection fraction was 60% with no wall motion abnormality. Transthoracic echocardiography also showed an unusual, tubular-like structure inside the interventricular septum with a turbulent, predominantly diastolic flow on color Doppler. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed a markedly dilated RCA arising from the right aortic sinus, while the origin of the left coronary artery (LCA) could not be demonstrated. There was a tortuous, abnormal vessel located adjacent to the main pulmonary artery (MPA) emptying into the posteromedial aspect of the MPA. There was an accelerated, continuous flow across the stenotic ostium. Moreover, there was severe MR from a restricted posterior leaflet of the mitral valve (MV) associated with ventricular remodeling in combination with mitral annular dilatation.
Coronary angiography with a single RCA injection revealed a markedly dilated RCA providing multiple intercoronary collaterals of various sizes communicating with the left coronary system. The LCA later opacified the MPA through a stenotic ostium, establishing the diagnostic hallmark of ALCAPA syndrome. The calculated ratio of pulmonary-systemic blood flow was 1.4, confirming a significant left-to-right shunt. Coronary computed tomography angiography clearly identified the ALCAPA with a retropulmonary ostium. Volume-rendered image depicted the course of the anomalous coronary arteries and its inter-coronary collateral pathways along the epicardial surface and where the LCA connected to the MPA. Stress cardiovascular magnetic resonance perfusion imaging demonstrated no myocardial ischemia, suggesting adequate collateral circulation to the LV.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with ALCAPA syndrome, a congenital heart defect, resulting in a left-to-right shunt, and severe MR. No myocardial ischemia was detected through stress cardiovascular magnetic resonance perfusion imaging. The patient's LV and LCA were dilated while also experiencing mitral annular dilatation. The disease was diagnosed and monitored through various tests and imaging, such as Transthoracic echocardiography, Transesophageal echocardiography, coronary angiography, and coronary computed tomography angiography. The patient was referred for appropriate follow-up care and treatment.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to abdominal pain, non-bloody diarrhea and weight loss. Physical examination demonstrated moderate abdominal tenderness with an abdominal mass in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory findings revealed a significantly elevated CRP level. Colonoscopy showed ulcerations localized at the Bauhin’s valve and histological examination of obtained mucosal biopsies were suggestive for active Crohn’s Disease (CD). MR enteroclysis was performed due to inability to intubate the terminal ileum and indicated a predominant inflammatory, short-segment stenosis of the terminal ileum. Medical treatment was switched from prednisolone and azathioprine to adalimumab. 

Course of Treatment:
Twelve weeks after induction of adalimumab therapy, clinical remission was achieved and CRP level returned to normal. Another four months later, the patient presented with severe pain in the mandibular area. A biopsy of the oral lesions was obtained and revealed ulcerative stomatitis with noncaseating granulomas consistent with oral CD. Intensification of immunosuppressive therapy was initiated by shortening the adalimumab administration interval to weekly administration. A follow-up examination after 10 weeks confirmed complete healing of the oral CD lesion. During a follow-up period of 12 months, no signs of active CD became evident under continued therapy. 

Summary:
This 34-year-old man with a 15-year history of Crohn’s Disease (CD) was admitted to our hospital due to abdominal pain, non-bloody diarrhea, and weight loss. The patient underwent MR enteroclysis and was found to have a predominant inflammatory, short-segment stenosis of the terminal ileum. After unsuccessful treatment with prednisolone and azathioprine, the patient was switched to adalimumab and achieved clinical remission after 12 weeks. Although the patient maintained clinical remission and low laboratory inflammation markers, the patient later presented with ulcerative lesions of the buccal-side mucosa of the right mandible consistent with oral CD. Intensification of immunosuppressive therapy was initiated by shortening the adalimumab administration interval to weekly administration. A follow-up examination confirmed complete healing of the oral CD lesion. The patient remained in remission for a 12 month follow-up period under continued therapy.

The patient was diagnosed with a GDC with no malignant transformation.

The prognosis is guarded due to the patient's history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy with left ventricular thrombus, and her recent infarction may aggravate the situation. 81-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presented with abdominal discomfort and distension. On physical examination, hepatomegaly was noted without jaundice, ascites, or hepatic encephalopathy. Laboratory data revealed platelet count of 101,000/mm3, total bilirubin of 0.9 mg/dL, AST of 33 IU/L, ALT of IU/L, and PT-INR of 1.15. Given the findings of four HCC lesions found in segments II, VI, and VIII, with the largest being near the liver capsule, segmental TACE with epirubicin and iodized oil was performed. Emergent CT scan showed intraperitoneal free air and a rupture of the HCC in segment II into the peritoneal cavity adjacent to the gastric wall. The patient was managed nonoperatively with piperacillin and tazobactam to control the formed abdominal abscess and was discharged after 18 days, with continued antimicrobial therapy. 

The patient was readmitted after five weeks with hematochezia and hemorrhagic shock. A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed gastric extraluminal compression by an HCC lesion and extravasation of contrast medium into the stomach. A submucosal tumor with central ulceration was detected on the anterior wall of the gastric body via upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The hemorrhage from the ulcer was treated after successful hypertonic saline-epinephrine injection. An additional submucosal tumor without ulcer formation was observed in the gastric fundus. The patient's condition stabilized, and he was discharged for palliative care. The patient subsequently expired six weeks after undergoing TACE.

The patient was admitted to the National University of Malaysia (UKM) Paediatric Dental Clinic with a referral for further management of pulp necrosis of an immature lower right second premolar (tooth 45), secondary to the fractured tubercle of dens evaginatus. The tooth had undergone root canal therapy by a general dental practitioner (GDP) due to spontaneous and lingering pain following cold and thermal stimuli. During the initial assessment, the pulp chamber was reentered and irrigated with saline, followed by the placement of a nonsetting calcium hydroxide material and a double sealing of the access cavity with Cavit™ 3M and glass ionomer cement (GIC) Riva Self Cure™ SDI.

Two weeks later, the tooth was reassessed and irrigated with a copious volume of 1.5% sodium hypochlorite (NaOCI) to remove the nonsetting calcium hydroxide, followed by irrigation with sterile water. The canal was then irrigated with 17% EDTA for a minute and dried with paper points, before being filled using the EndoSequence (BC RRM-Fast Set Putty, Brasseler, USA) material under the guidance of a dental operating microscope Carl Zeiss Surgical GmbH, S100). The orifice of the root canal was double sealed with a cotton pellet, temporary filling material (Cavit 3M, USA), and GIC (Riva Self Cure SDI, Australia).

Two weeks later, the root canal was reaccessed again, irrigated with 1.5% NaOCl, and dried with paper points. The canal was then obturated with thermoplasticised gutta-perca using the Obtura III Max System (Obtura Spartan® Endodontics). The patient was evaluated clinically for features of NF1, and multiple café au lait macules were subsequently discovered on his trunk. The patient underwent several courses of radiotherapy and is currently eighteen months disease-free.

Physical Examination:

On physical examination, the patient appeared well with a normal affect. The patient's thyroid was palpable and smooth with no lymphadenopathy. The patient's chest, heart, abdomen, genitalia, and skin were all normal. The patient's Tanner stage 1 genital development and 3 cc testes were noted.

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's medical history and physical examination, the patient was diagnosed with extreme obesity.

The patient was referred for further follow-up and treatment with an endocrinologist. No other follow-up was noted in the patient's medical records.

Hospital Course:
A 58-year-old man with recurrent headache, transient loss of consciousness, and progressive memory loss was admitted to the hospital. Eight years before admission, he was diagnosed with possible tuberculous meningitis, for which he received empirical anti-tuberculous treatment for more than 1 year. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with possible cryptococcal meningitis and received fluconazole and amphotericin B treatment. Three months before admission, he developed progressive memory loss. 

Diagnostic Studies:
Brain MRI showed an enhanced lesion posterior to the medulla and hydrocephalus. Nucleic acid sequencing of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) identified T. solium DNA sequence. Plain x-rays showed scattered “cigar-shaped” calcified lesions in the legs and thoracic wall. Serum and CSF samples were both positive for C. cellulosae IgG antibodies. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with intraventricular neurocysticercosis (NCC), likely resulting from Taenia solium infection.

Therapeutic Interventions:
The patient was treated with albendazole and dexamethasone, both of which led to improvement in his symptoms and CSF findings.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with instructions to complete his course of medications and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation. 

Prognosis:
The patient is expected to make a full recovery from his intraventricular NCC with appropriate medical management.

Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:

Lung metastasis from hepatocellular carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung

Hospital Course:

The patient received radiotherapy to the lung metastasis according to the method described hereinafter. Planning CT images were acquired under deep inspiration breath-hold condition with a commercial gold coil marker, Visicoil 21G slim line (IBA Dosimetry, Schwarzenbruck, Germany) of diameter 0.5mm and length 10mm, implanted using CT guidance as close as possible to a tumor. A single-arc coplanar VMAT plan (gantry rotation from 320° to 100°) was created with an isotropic planning target volume (PTV) margin of 5mm and a prescribed dose of 60Gy in 20 fractions. Multiple breath-holds were required to complete the delivery.

During the segmented VMAT beam delivery, the implant marker stayed at the planned breath-hold position, and a DRR image at the gantry start angle was created for each segment. Breath-hold training was given to the patient for optimizing the breath-hold and the following free-breathing periods to successfully complete each segmented breath-hold VMAT delivery.

Subsequently, two lateral lines were manually copied onto a fluoroscopic image window of the XVI display using a transparent sheet. Each line was used as a tolerance limit for the breath-hold beam delivery. During the beam delivery, the breath-hold status was continuously monitored to ensure that the marker position stayed within the tolerance range. If the marker moved outside the tolerance range, beam delivery was interrupted, and the procedure was repeated.

Breath-hold CBCT imaging was performed to confirm that the marker position relative to the tumor remained unchanged. The total VMAT delivery time for a prescribed fraction dose of 3Gy was approximately 115sec, with three beam interrupts and a 25 sec segmented beam delivery followed by 20 sec free breathing.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of lung metastasis from hepatocellular carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung.

The patient was discharged to an outpatient clinic for follow-up and further treatment.

The patient was in a stable condition, with no complications reported during hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with multiple liver lesions involving 70% of the right liver, multiple nodules in the left lobe, and right portal thrombosis in the setting of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Hospital Course:
The patient initially received systemic treatment with sorafenib in December 2012. However, the medication was discontinued after ten days due to G3 skin toxicity (Stevens–Johnson syndrome). In January 2013, the patient started metronomic capecitabine (500 mg twice daily, continuous administration), which was well-tolerated. A new CT scan in March 2013 showed significant intralesional necrosis, and subsequent FDG-PET scanning in April 2013 showed the complete absence of any pathological areas. AFP level had also fallen to 3.3 ng/mL.

In July 2013, a needle biopsy of the principal hepatic lesion revealed fibrous connective tissue with histiocytic inflammation without any tumour cells. An abdominal US scan in January 2014 revealed the presence of a single hypoechoic lesion of 1.4 × 1.3 cm. Subsequent CT scanning in December 2014 also showed a further reduction in the size of the hepatic lesion without any vascular components, for which it was decided to discontinue treatment in the same month.

The most recent US scan in September 2017 showed no hepatic lesion, and serum AFP was 3.6 ng/mL. The patient is currently alive and in excellent health.

Condition at discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition without any significant medical issues.

Follow-up and care plan:
The patient was advised to continue with periodic follow-up appointments with his physician to monitor his condition and AFP levels. In case of any significant change in his medical condition, he was advised to seek immediate medical attention.

Summary:
The patient presented with multiple liver lesions and right portal thrombosis in the setting of NASH. He was initially treated with sorafenib but discontinued due to G3 skin toxicity. He was subsequently treated with metronomic capecitabine, which was well-tolerated and resulted in significant intralesional necrosis. The patient then underwent a needle biopsy, which showed no tumour cells. A subsequent US scan showed the presence of a single hepatic lesion, which gradually resolved over time, and he was finally discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were advised to monitor the patient's condition.

Admitting Diagnosis: Incidental finding of mediastinal mass overlapping the aortic arch region

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital by her family doctor after receiving a chest x-ray during routine clinical examination, which showed a mediastinal mass overlapping the aortic arch region. A computed tomography (CT) was performed and revealed incidentally a type B dissection, which was most likely chronic without information of the index date, originating from an aneurysm of a left cervical arch with a maximum diameter of 6 cm. The left renal artery, the celiac trunk and the main part of the superior mesenteric artery branched from the false lumen without a sign of malperfusion of the organs.

Before intervention, the patient received a blood pressure adjustment by ACE inhibitor. Betablocker was not necessary because of a resting pulse under 60 beats per minute. For neurological online monitoring, sensitive and motor evoked potentials were monitored. Spinal drainage was installed 1 day before the procedure.

Surgical access was carried out through median sternotomy and an additional left lateral thoracic incision through the fourth intercostal space (Hemi-Clemshell). Simultaneously to the preparation of the aneurysm, partial cardiopulmonary bypass was installed in the left groin by cannulation of the femoral artery and vein under echocardiographic guidance. During selective ventilation of the right side, the left lung was mobilized by transsection of the Ligamentum pulmonale and preparation of the perianeurysmatic tissue and adhesions.

After identification and preparation of the recurrent and phrenic nerve and the supraaortal branches, the descending aorta was clamped. The left carotid artery originated from the aortic arch with a distance of only 1 cm from the aneurysm. The left axillary artery branched directly from the aneurysm and was dissected and reimplanted with a separate sidegraft to the straight graft between the distal arch and proximal descending aorta.

The procedure was performed with partial cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) of 87 min, aortic clamp time of 62 min under normothermic condition. The patient was extubated on first postoperative day and recovered well.

Biopsy of aortic tissue showed a picture consistent with arteriosclerosis and loss of smooth muscle cells, rupture of the elastic fibers and fibrosis of the media. The intima could not be visualized in detail.

The patient was discharged to cardiac rehabilitation at 13th postoperative day and recovered well.

Follow Up and Recommendations:

Last follow up with computed tomography was performed 3, 5 years after initial operation with a good and stable result of the dissection membrane and a perfusion of both lumina. The patient is able to resume a normal life without limitations.

The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician for routine check-ups and to maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Diagnoses:
- Catheter-related deep venous thrombosis

- Small bowel obstruction secondary to submucosal hematoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our pediatric intensive care unit with a persistent seizure disorder of unknown cause. A right femoral triple lumen central venous line had been placed previously. After five days, he developed an acute occlusive deep venous thrombosis in the right common femoral vein, which was treated with LMWH (enoxaparin) at 1 mg/kg for a planned three-month course, with the CVL being removed five days after initiating anticoagulation. The patient had no personal or family history of thrombophilia or bleeding diathesis. 

During his hospital course, he experienced multisystem organ failure secondary to DRESS syndrome as a result of anticonvulsive therapy. One week after starting LMWH heparin, he developed gross hematuria. In the setting of his anti-Xa levels continuing to rise, LMWH heparin was held, and anticoagulation was switched to unfractionated heparin. The patient required continuous venovenous hemofiltration and eventually, a steady regimen was found with consistently stable and therapeutic anti-Xa levels. 

Unfortunately, on the 15th day of this regimen, the patient developed signs of bowel obstruction with copious bilious vomiting. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed a high-grade small bowel obstruction, with 2 areas of small bowel, suspicious for intussusception. An exploratory laparotomy was done, and 30 cm of the distal jejunum was found to be severely compromised and was resected. Pathologic analysis showed an extensive submucosal hematoma causing internal bulging of the mucosa and submucosa, causing attenuation and focal pressure necrosis of the muscularis propria.

Treatment:
The patient's submucosal hematoma was successfully resected, and he recovered in the pediatric ICU without further episodes of emesis or signs of bowel obstruction. Five days after the operation, he was restarted on LMWH, and he completed his 3-month course without any further signs of bleeding. He was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks later with resolution of his seizures to a rehabilitation facility.

Follow-up:
The patient will need to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his seizure disorder. A referral to a hematologist may be considered for further evaluation of the catheter-related deep venous thrombosis and his complex anticoagulation course. Follow-up with gastroenterology may also be considered for further management of his bowel obstruction.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the pediatric ICU with findings of severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with circulating blasts. Initial workup revealed a diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), confirmed by molecular analysis of the peripheral blood. The patient was treated emergently with ATRA, dexamethasone, allopurinol, cefepime, and blood products including packed red blood cells, platelets, and cryoprecipitate. She received several transfusions with platelets, cryoprecipitate, and fresh frozen plasma to manage DIC. She was continued on an induction course of chemotherapy including ATRA, dexamethasone, idarubicin, and arsenic trioxide. A lumbar puncture was performed and intrathecal chemotherapy was administered, which revealed the presence of leukemia cells in the cerebrospinal fluid, confirming the involvement of the central nervous system. The patient's encephalopathy gradually improved and she returned to her baseline mental status by day 7 of treatment. The patient was noted to have elevated opening pressure on lumbar punctures, which worsened over the course of induction, attributed to pseudotumor cerebri secondary to ATRA. Upon completion of the first 28 days of induction therapy, repeat lumbar puncture and bone marrow studies demonstrated no morphologic evidence of acute promyelocytic leukemia, consistent with remission.
