Hospital Course:

The patient [Patient's name] was admitted to the hospital with complaints of headache, bilateral pelvic sensitivity and a mass painful to touch in a plastic texture in the Douglas' pouch. During the examination, a mass was detected which was evaluated in favor of leiomyoma. The patient's laboratory reports, including ß-hcg, wbc, hgb, htc, and plt were within the normal range. Ultrasonography revealed a mass consistent with a degenerated myoma measuring 77x82mm, of which subserous component was greater in the posterior wall. The MRI scan also revealed a mass with a hypovascular appearance following a heterogeneous and hypointense IV contrast material with a diameter of 8 mm, which appeared to displace the posterior cervix.

Following necessary preparations, laparoscopic myomectomy was performed. Myoma was removed by morcellating in an isolated bag, and surgery was uneventful. The pathology report, however, revealed a marked cellularity and pleomorphism, extensive necrosis, mitosis >5/10BBA, KI67 proliferation index >%50, weak positivity for p53, and LMS with no detectable lymphovascular invasion. The patient was informed about the pathology report and interned again to perform transabdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salphingoopherectomy. The pathology report revealed an atypical pleomorphic fusiform cell proliferation area in a focal area within the cavity consistent with residual LMS when evaluated together with laparoscopic myomectomy material.

After 3 months from her 1st surgery, PET-CT was performed, and fluoro-2-deoxyglucose (FDG) uptake was noted in the area above rectosigmoid mesentery towards the left abdominal wall in pelvic floor. The patient was referred to a gynecologic oncologist, and a 3rd operation was performed. A mass about 4-5 cm of size in defined localization was excised; there was not any other mass and lymphadenopathy detected during the surgery. The pathology result was high grade malign mesenchymal tumor with high cellularity, extensive necrosis, mitosis 40/10 BBA, and moderate atypia. There was no tumor in surgical margin. The patient is now being followed up by the gynecologic oncologist with appropriate medical treatment. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Leiomyoma with LMS found in pathology reports.

Discharge Instructions and Follow-Up:

The patient [Patient's name] was discharged with instructions to continue her medications as prescribed. She was advised to follow up on the recommended course of medical treatment. The patient should attend her follow-up appointments with the gynecologic oncologist. If the patient experiences any unusual symptoms or side effects, it is recommended that she contact her gynecologic oncologist.

Diagnosis: Gastrointestinal disease

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of constipation for 5 days, followed by diarrhea with abdominal distension. Upon admission, she presented with extensive abdominal tenderness and a fecal occult blood test was positive. Serological markers for autoimmunity and viral serology were normal, as were stool examinations for bacteria and parasites.

Abdominal X-ray revealed multiple intraluminal gas pockets in the left colon, and colonoscopy revealed grape-like or beaded subepithelial lesions with erythematous mucosa distributed in the sigmoid. The endoscopic ultrasonography showed low echo of cystic below the mucosal layer.

High frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts was performed but only partial treatment was necessary due to the risk of infection. The patient was placed on a restricted diet and given parenteral nutrition. Ornidazole and vitamin B2 were administered to regulate intestinal anaerobes, and bifidobacterium was given to aid in digestion.

One week later, the patient was able to consume a half-fluid diet. Her condition steadily improved over the next two weeks, with the lesions disappearing completely one month later. NBI showed patchy erythema and yellow nodules. After four months of follow-up, the patient remained asymptomatic with normal colonoscopy findings.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition. Instructions were provided to avoid gas-producing foods and to maintain a low-diet. She will receive follow-up care with specialists in gastroenterology and nutritional therapy.

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with locally advanced papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) that had invaded the trachea, esophagus, and left recurrent nerve. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with bilateral modified radical neck dissection, followed by a window resection of the trachea. The patient was then diagnosed with PTC, pT4aN1bM0, stage IVA. A one-stage reconstruction was performed using an auricular deltopectoral flap. 

Hospital Course:
The operation was successful, but a final histopathological estimation of the tracheal margin was positive. Three months after the operation, a recurrent tumor was detected outside the left piriform fossa and was given 100 mCi of I-131 therapy. Nine months after the operation, the patient experienced apparent dyspnea and a dull pain in the right shoulder. A CT scan revealed prominent tumor progression in both the neck and the lung, and bone scintigraphy showed bone metastasis in the right scapula. The patient underwent EBRT for the recurrent neck tumor (60 Gy) and the right scapula (36 Gy), and docetaxel was administered once per 3 weeks for 24 months. The lung metastasis was exceptionally enlarged, but the docetaxel was temporarily very effective for the local recurrence. Three years after the operation, the patient was started with the newly emerged TKI sorafenib. However, because of the exacerbation of lung metastasis, it was terminated in 9 months. Therefore, 45 months after the operation, lenvatinib was started, which showed remarkable improvement for the tumor and lung metastasis.

Hospital Course:
This is a case report of a 44-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2006 and underwent modified radical mastectomy after excisional biopsy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient was found to have metastatic lung cancer secondary to breast cancer in June 2010, which was treated with an ovariectomy and exemestane. The patient complained of severe cough in March 2014 and was found to have metastases in the lungs and mediastinal lymph nodes, as well as a malignant renal mass. Various chemotherapy regimens were employed, but all failed. A biopsy of the metastatic lesion was performed, confirming lung metastasis of breast cancer with increased expression of ER. The patient was started on fulvestrant and zoledronic acid injections in August 2015, and a partial response was achieved with shrinking of the renal mass and improvement in subjective symptoms. The patient was stable for 16 months until December 2016 when she decided to stop taking fulvestrant. The patient died of epilepsia gravior due to brain metastases in November 2018 after being treated with apatinib.

Hospital Course:
The 72-year-old male patient was admitted with persistent pain in the left side of the waist for 2 years. He was diagnosed with schistosomiasis 40 years ago and was also found to have hypertension 1 year ago. The patient had pain on movement of the spine with bilateral Grade IV motor strength in both lower extremities and was diagnosed with a spinal cord and nerve root compression caused by an expanding mass partly protruding into the vertebral canal.

Diagnostic Findings:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT) scans were performed which showed an elliptical abnormal signal shadow in the left side of the vertebral body and left peritoneum indicative of a dumbbell growth. The MRI scan showed an area of increased signal intensity on T2-weighted images in the T12-L4 paravertebral region. At discovery, a slightly longer T1/T2 signal was observed with a size of 8.6 × 8.4 × 12.4 cm on the left side of the L1 vertebral body. The boundary was clear, and an uneven separation was observed. The lesion protruded into the erector spinae muscles and behind the retroperitoneum. The spinal cord was compressed, and the boundary was clear. Bone destruction was observable on the left lateral transverse process of L2, and the left kidney was significantly compressed.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical resection of the total tumor followed by spinal internal fixation of L1 to L2 with pedicle screws. Total laminectomy was performed for L1 and L2. Histopathological examination showed the presence of a lobulated neoplasm in a prominent extracellular myxoid matrix. The neoplastic cells were composed of syncytial cords of "physaliphorous cells" that contained abundant pale septated and vacuolated clear to bubbly cytoplasm with mild nuclear pleomorphism. Overt mitosis was not identified. Immunohistochemical examination showed that the lesional cells were positive to CK (+++), S100 (++), CD65 (+), neuron-specific enolase (++), epithelial membrane antigen (+++), and vimentin (+++). The coexpression of epithelial and mesenchymal immunohistochemical markers supported the notochordal lineage of the lesional cells. Ki67 was 3%+ in the lesional cells. The above histomorphological features in conjunction with the immune-phenotype observed confirmed the diagnosis of chordoma.

Outcome:
No heavy ion radiotherapy was performed because the tumor massively invaded into spinal canal and foramen, compressing the spinal cord and nerve root directly. After 5-month follow-up, recurrence was found in the original lesion through the post-operative CT. Due to the complexity and size of the recurrence, a second operation was not possible. At the 15-month follow-up, the patient was deceased after various doctor visits.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 10-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right-sided flank pain that had been persistent for the last two days. The pain had worsened when the patient was laying down but was relieved to some extent with paracetamol. The initial examinations revealed no abnormalities in the observations, blood tests, or urine tests. Because of the lack of any surgical or medical cause of pain, it was assumed that the pain was musculoskeletal in origin and was associated with playing netball.

However, the patient represented the next day with further complaints of pain, and additional examinations revealed that she was tachycardic and tachypnoeic with a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute. In addition, the patient was found to have guarding with rebound tenderness in the right flank and hypochondrium. She was then admitted to the hospital because of repeated presentations with abdominal pain and a rising CRP and white cell count.

A computed tomography (CT) scan was arranged, which revealed an organizing right lower lobe pneumonia with a small effusion. The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics for the silent pneumonia. Nevertheless, the pneumonia progressed, and the patient developed a large parapneumonic effusion. Further, the CRP and white cell count in the blood continued to rise, and the patient showed signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. 

The patient was stabilized and transferred to a tertiary hospital. At the tertiary center, a chest drain was inserted, and intrapleural urokinase therapy and intravenous antibiotics were given. After 2 weeks of treatment, the patient was discharged.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow the prescribed course of antibiotics as directed by the physician until the course is completed. She is also advised to continue regular analgesia and to avoid playing netball until fully recovered. In addition, the patient has been instructed to follow up with her primary care physician within 1-2 weeks to monitor her progress. 

Adverse Reactions:
No adverse reactions have been noted during this hospitalization.

Follow Up:
The patient has been advised to follow up with her primary care physician within 1-2 weeks to monitor her progress and assess any new symptoms.

Patient was discharged from our hospital following treatment for right-lateral chest and back pain. The patient's medical history includes concurrent bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and total hysterectomy for right ovarian tumor.

Physical examination findings included deep-tendon hyperreflexia in the lower extremities but no muscle weakness. Blood test results were unremarkable, apart from a high serum concentration of cancer antigen 125. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the right arch of Th12 vertebral bone that protruded into the spinal canal. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the mass revealed no evidence of malignancy.

Pathological examination of a CT-guided needle biopsy of the paraspinal lesion demonstrated papillary proliferation of epithelial cells. The neoplastic cells showed positive results for paired box 8 (PAX8), estrogen receptor (ER), and Wilms’ tumor 1 (WT1), but negative for thyroglobulin, thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1), progesterone receptor, S100 protein, and calretinin. Staining for P53 showed a non-mutational “wild type” pattern. It was concluded that the paraspinal lesion was a bone metastasis of transformed LGSC originating from the previous SBT/APST in the right ovary.

The patient underwent radiotherapy for the paraspinal lesion, followed by chemotherapy treatment with paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab. The treatment successfully relieved the patient's pain. Currently, the patient presents with right-sided pleural effusion and suspected metastases in the Th3 and Th4 vertebrae, 168 months after the initial surgery.

In regards to diagnosis, the patient was evaluated with physical examination, blood tests, imaging studies, and pathological examination. The patient was diagnosed with a bone metastasis of transformed LGSC originating from the previous SBT/APST in the right ovary.

The patient was treated with radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy treatment with paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab. The treatments were effective in relieving the patient's pain.

The patient is to continue follow-up appointments with their provider as scheduled.

The patient, a 77-year-old male with stage IV lung SCC and metastasis to the liver, was admitted to the hospital for fatigue complaints after being treated with nivolumab. The patient had continued to show stable disease while on nivolumab, until day 1 of cycle 8 when he complained of profound fatigue.

The patient's random cortisol level was found to be 1.3 μg/dL and did not satisfactorily respond to the ACTH stimulation test. His ACTH level was <5 pg/mL.

The patient was diagnosed with immune-related central adrenal insufficiency.

As the patient's symptoms were resolved immediately after dexamethasone and hydrocortisone were administered, he was started on hydrocortisone and opted to discontinue nivolumab. The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to continue taking hydrocortisone as prescribed. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the primary care physician to monitor the patient's condition.

The final diagnosis for the patient was immune-related central adrenal insufficiency.

Reason for Admission: Idiopathic central precocious puberty             
Treatment Provided: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg every 28 days                

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 7-year and 6-month-old girl, was admitted to our hospital due to premature thelarche. She had no significant medical history. Upon examination, her height was 131.5 cm, and breast development was found to be at Tanner stage 3. Diagnostic test results revealed that she had idiopathic central precocious puberty. Treatment with GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg every 28 days was initiated. After 6 months, a follow-up LHRH test showed suppressed gonadotropin peaks, confirming the effectiveness of the treatment.

On the day the patient turned 8 years and 4 months old, she was readmitted to our Emergency Department for the occurrence of abdominal pain, burning sensation at neck and dyspnea that developed two hours after the previous injection of the GnRH analogue therapy. She was found to have pruriginous whistles all over her body, and a diagnosis of anaphylactic reactions was made. Treatment with systemic epinephrine and intravenous hydrocortisone was administered, and the symptoms were effectively resolved. Skin prick tests conducted the following day indicated a positive result at very low dilution of the drug (1:10.000); consequently, therapy with triptorelin was discontinued.

The patient was closely monitored for 6 months following the incident, and no further instances of anaphylactic reactions were reported at any point. Moreover, there was no significant progression of puberty in the six months of follow-up.

Follow-up and Recommendations:

The patient is recommended to avoid the use of GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg. If any further signs of precocious puberty are observed, please contact a medical professional for alternative treatment options.

Overall, the patient’s condition has been managed effectively with the timely treatment of GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg. The patient’s anaphylactic reaction to the therapy is a documented and significant problem, and it is important for medical professionals to take note of this and keep this information on record.

Patient: 53-year-old male with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted with severe generalized muscle weakness and myalgias. He had been diagnosed with Grade 2 esophageal varices, ascites, and hepatic encephalopathy in 2016. The patient was afebrile, tachycardic, and mildly hypertensive on presentation. Physical examination was remarkable for symmetrical proximal muscle tenderness and weakness. Laboratory findings showed elevations in creatinine, aspartate aminotransferase (AST), white blood cells (WBC), and creatine kinase (CK).
The etiology of patient’s rhabdomyolysis was unclear, but infectious, autoimmune, and malignant causes were investigated and excluded. The patient was aggressively treated with intravenous fluid resuscitation, and his myoglobinuria resolved soon after. Further medication review revealed that the patient had been recently started on rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy prophylaxis. Rifaximin has been occasionally reported to cause rhabdomyolysis in patients with hepatic insufficiency. The patient improved dramatically after cessation of the drug.
The patient’s strength continued to improve with therapy, and he was discharged on day 16 with a diagnosis of rifaximin-induced rhabdomyolysis.

Diagnoses:
1. Alcoholic cirrhosis
2. Rifaximin-induced rhabdomyolysis

The patient should follow up with his primary care physician.

Hospital Course:

The 59-year-old male patient had presented with nausea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. He had previously been diagnosed with a stage T1A nonsmall cell lung cancer in the right upper lobe. The patient had refused surgery and completed Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT). Serial surveillance imaging showed no abnormalities until the current presentation. 

Diagnostic Assessment:

A total body PET-CT scan was ordered due to the patient's prior history of cancer. The results showed thickening of the wall of the gastric fundus and a mass in the tail of the pancreas. Additionally, a 1.1-cm filling defect within the splenic vein was observed. Upper endoscopy revealed a 5-cm infiltrative and ulcerated mass in the gastric fundus. Gastric biopsies showed poorly differentiated carcinoma. EUS confirmed a hypoechoic round mass in the pancreas with local vascular involvement and splenic vein thrombus and was diagnosed with neuroendocrine carcinoma.

Treatment:

Treatment options, including palliative care, were discussed with the patient and his family, and the patient elected to receive symptomatic treatment.

Conclusion:

Metastasis of the primary lung tumor to the stomach is infrequent and sporadic. Symptomatic cases present with epigastric pain, chronic anemia, signs of GI bleed (hematemesis, melena), and gastric perforations. The patient's case illustrates the potential for cancer to spread via hematogenous and lymphatic routes. EUS-FNA in combination with immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing metastatic lesions and differentiating those from synchronous primary lesions.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 49-year-old male

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the hospital with spontaneous bruising and mucosal bleeding. He had a platelet count of 2 × 10^9/L, which improved with the administration of prednisone. Despite laparoscopic splenectomy and various treatments, the patient experienced cyclic thrombocytopenia for over 10 years, with platelet counts fluctuating with a statistically significant period of 39 days.

Hospital Course:
The patient received treatment with corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin, danazol, pulse dexamethasone, and rituximab, but none were effective in resolving the persistent thrombocytopenia. Serial measurements of thrombopoietin (TPO) levels were taken, which revealed undetectable levels during periods of extreme thrombocytosis and increased levels when platelet counts were low.

Treatment:
Treatment with the TPO receptor agonist eltrombopag was started and timed with anticipated periods of thrombocytopenia. The patient received 50 mg of eltrombopag daily during specific periods, resulting in extreme thrombocytosis that did not alter the cycle pattern or period. Therefore, eltrombopag was discontinued thereafter.

Summary:
The patient presented with thrombocytopenia, which improved with prednisone and laparoscopic splenectomy. However, the thrombocytopenia relapsed and persisted for over 10 years. Serial measurements of TPO levels were taken, and treatment with eltrombopag was started and then discontinued due to its ineffectiveness in resolving the cyclic thrombocytopenia.

Following the procedure, the patient was prescribed a combination of immunosuppressant medications but continued to require frequent doses of intravenous immunoglobulin and corticosteroids due to persistent severe thrombocytopenia. 
In April 2003, the patient experienced periodic oscillations in platelet count levels with a statistically significant period of 23 days. The patient frequently reported bleeding with oral mucosal blood blisters during episodes of severe thrombocytopenia. Despite the addition of danazol to the treatment regimen, the patient's platelet count levels remained unstable.
After six years, eltrombopag was introduced and led to extreme thrombocytosis. As a result, all immunosuppressant medications were stopped and the patient experienced a period of severe thrombocytopenia for approximately 4 weeks. Subsequently, eltrombopag was slowly reintroduced and the cyclical thrombocytopenia became less severe over time. At the last follow-up in May 2015, the patient was prescribed eltrombopag 75 mg daily along with low doses of azathioprine and mycophenolate.

Diagnosis:
Severe thrombocytopenia 

Clinical Findings:
Platelet count levels began oscillating periodically with a statistically significant period of 23 days from a nadir of <10 × 109/L and a peak of 300-400 × 109/L. During episodes of severe thrombocytopenia, the patient frequently had bleeding with oral mucosal blood blisters. 

Treatment:
The patient was previously prescribed a combination of immunosuppressant medications, intravenous immunoglobulin, and corticosteroids. Following the introduction of eltrombopag, all immunosuppressant medications were stopped and the patient's condition improved. At present, the patient is prescribed eltrombopag 75 mg daily along with low doses of azathioprine and mycophenolate.

Prognosis:
The cyclical pattern of thrombocytopenia gradually resolved over time and the patient's condition is currently stable. Please continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: May 2013 
Discharge Date: July 2013 
Principal Diagnosis: MDS with excess blasts: refractory anemia with excess blasts-1 (RAEB-1)

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 75-year-old Caucasian man, was admitted for bicytopenia in May 2013. His initial blood cell count showed hemoglobin 8 g/dl, platelets 87 × 109/l, and leukocytes 6.1 × 109/L. He had a medical history of T2D treated with biphasic insulin aspart and triple-bypass surgery for coronary disease in 2010. No family history of hematological malignancies was noted. He was hospitalized in an intensive care unit for grade IV anemia and then transferred to the hematology department after blood transfusions. Bone marrow aspiration showed multilineage dysplasia with 8% of blasts, consistent with a diagnosis of MDS with excess blasts: refractory anemia with excess blasts-1 (RAEB-1).

The patient was initially treated with darbepoetin 300 μg per week, without response. A second bone marrow aspiration two months later showed 29% of blasts, consistent with the diagnosis of AML progression. He consented to participate in a phase I–II clinical research study assessing the combination of 5-azacitidine with idarubicin in July 2013. He showed a partial response with 8% of bone marrow blasts after six cycles, and transfusion independence.

However, the patient reported higher blood glucose levels 2–3 days after the start of each 5-azacitidine cycle, requiring an increased dose of self-administered insulin. Further monitoring confirmed higher blood glucose levels from days 4 to 12 of each 5-azacitidine cycle. No change in diet or in physical activities was noted. Our patient experienced such dysregulation during all the additional 15 cycles until a fatal progression of AML.

Impression:

The patient was admitted with bicytopenia and diagnosed with MDS with excess blasts: refractory anemia with excess blasts-1 (RAEB-1). After no response to initial treatment, he participated in a clinical research study and experienced a partial response. However, he had blood glucose dysregulation during the treatment cycles. Unfortunately, he experienced a fatal progression of AML.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 62-year-old male

Admitted: with dyspnea and chest pain

Diagnosis: Cardiac tamponade caused by metastatic urothelial carcinoma (UC) with pericardial effusion

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with progressive dyspnea and chest pain. On examination, he had a heart rate of 136 bpm, blood pressure of 122/74 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, and O2 saturation of 98% on room air. Heart sounds were muffled, and heart rhythm was irregularly irregular. Distention of the jugular veins was observed, and Kussmaul's sign was present. Although pulsus paradoxus was not observed, other physical findings were extremely concerning for cardiac tamponade. Bibasilar crackles were present on lung auscultation. Laboratory data was remarkable for a creatinine of 1.42 and INR of 3.6 (on warfarin for a history of pulmonary embolism). His electrocardiogram revealed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate (RVR) and electrical alternans. Chest radiograph showed enlargement of the cardiac silhouette.

A bedside transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was obtained, which showed a large pericardial effusion with diastolic compression of the right ventricle, suggestive of cardiac tamponade, as well as mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction (see Figures and ). The patient's INR was reversed to <1.5, and he underwent emergent subxiphoid pericardial window with the removal of 700 ml of turbid, dark, bloody pericardial fluid. He had significant improvement in hemodynamics and respiratory distress. The pericardial fluid cytology and pericardial biopsy were both positive for malignancy, consistent with metastatic UC (see ).

One week after the pericardial window, the patient underwent a computerized tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, which did not show evidence of metastatic disease elsewhere. Given the recurrence of UC with metastasis to the pericardium, he was started on atezolizumab. Subsequently, he was noted to have recurrent pericardial effusion suggesting failure of treatment (see ). He was then started on pemetrexed, a folate antimetabolite chemotherapy drug, for metastatic UC with plans to complete 6 cycles.

Recommendation:

The patient requires close follow-up with his oncology team to monitor response to treatment and recurrence. He should receive regular cardiovascular evaluations due to his history of cardiac tamponade. It is recommended that the patient be advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow-up with his healthcare provider as needed.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was instructed on the importance of following up with his healthcare provider and oncology team. He should continue taking his medications as prescribed and should not miss any scheduled appointments. It is recommended that the patient seek medical attention immediately if he experiences any symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient's past medical history was not significant.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was scheduled for hysteroscopy and diagnostic laparoscopy. She also gave consent for possible open Strassmans metroplasty.

On hysteroscopy, a normal looking endometrium was visualized with a right-sided tubal ostia and a small tubal ostia on the left that did not appear to be patent. Laparoscopically, a bicornuate uterus was found with associated endometriosis at the vesicouterine fold. Open metroplasty was done. A copper intrauterine device was left in situ to separate the uterine walls and possibly reduce the chances of uterine synechiae. In addition, endometriotic deposits discovered at the vesico uterine fold were ablated.

The patient had an unremarkable follow-up after surgery with no complications reported. A HSG 6 months after surgery revealed unification of the uterine horns but both tubes were not delineated.

Patient was lost to follow-up but two years later she presented having conceived spontaneously and a TVS revealed a single intrauterine pregnancy at 13 weeks. Her antenatal workup was as highlighted in the medical record.

At 33 weeks, the patient presented with a history of lower abdominal pain worsening over the past few weeks and right-sided fundal tenderness pain score of seven out of ten on the pain assessment scale. The patient did not have any features suggestive of bowel obstruction and had a normal NST and an obstetric ultrasound that was done showed a single intrauterine pregnancy with normal biophysical profile and no features of placental abruption or slower uterine segment site dehiscence. The pain was significant enough to warrant an admission for which she subsequently received antenatal steroids for lung maturity and opioid analgesia for pain relief. However, the pain did not completely resolve and she underwent a cesarean delivery at 33 weeks and 5 days due to persistent lower abdominal pain. The outcome was a live male infant with a birth weight of 1950 grams and APGAR of 9, 10, 10. There was no evidence of uterine rupture although she had venous congestion and massive varicose veins bilaterally at the cornual areas. The previous metroplasty scar was intact.

The patient had a resolution of the abdominal pain postoperatively and had an unremarkable postoperative recovery. She was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.

1. Bicornuate uterus
2. Endometriosis
3. Pregnancy complicated by abdominal pain

2. Rest at home and avoid heavy lifting or strenuous activity.

4. Monitor any unusual or persistent abdominal pain and report to the obstetrician immediately.

Discharge Summary:

History and Admission:
A 47-year-old male with a fever, asthenia, and lumbar pain with signs of diffuse petechiae was admitted to the hospital. He became severely hypovolemic and tachycardic, showing also metabolic acidosis with high lactate levels. Blood cultures were taken, and empirical antibiotic therapy was administered. The diagnoses confirmed septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection (Serotype C).

Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred to the ICU and underwent norepinephrine and epinephrine infusions. Inflammation was controlled with PCT test, which showed extremely high levels. The patient's condition worsened with a bleeding disorder, severe hypotension, and oligoanuria. Hemofiltration treatment was necessary, followed by the installation of Cytosorb to the CVVH circuit the next day.

Discharge:
Within the course of 72-hour Cytosorb treatments, the patient's condition improved. The hemodynamic state stabilized, lactate and inflammation values decreased. The patient showed decreased disseminated intravascular coagulopathy, demarcation of skin necrosis areas, and a recovery of vital functions. The patient was extubated 10 days after admission and weaned from CVVH 12 days after the ICU admission. After 23 days from recovery, the patient was transferred to rehabilitation medicine, waiting for plastic surgeon consultant for amputation of some phalanges.

Admitting Diagnosis: High-grade brainstem tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old Caucasian female, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right hemiparesis, numbness, dysphagia, and ataxia. These symptoms began as numbness over her right scapular area two weeks prior, and the numbness later progressed to include the right leg. Additionally, she reported five days of waking up during the night with severe headaches, which were different in nature from her previous migraines. After workup in the emergency department and neurology consultation, the patient was referred to neurosurgery for management of a high-grade brainstem tumor.
On initial presentation, the patient's pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light, and her cranial nerves were grossly intact. Motor testing revealed that strength was 5/5 in both upper and lower extremities, and dysmetria was noted in the right upper extremity during finger-to-nose testing. The patient experienced a progressive decline during her initial admission, to include mild left facial droop, dysarthria, and worsening dysphagia. These symptoms continued until her initial discharge. Upon readmission, the patient displayed similar findings, including left lower quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder and acute numbness of the left chest and shoulder. These symptoms progressed and worsened until the patient was intubated after deteriorating to a GCS score of 10.
The patient underwent a closed stereotactic needle biopsy, during which biopsy samples were successfully obtained for pathologic examination. Postoperatively, a nasogastric tube was placed to provide nutrition, due to worsening dysphagia. On Day 10 of her hospitalization, a PEG tube was placed. The patient was scheduled for chemotherapy and craniospinal radiation therapy, and was discharged on Day 12. Four days later, the patient returned due to worsening symptoms, and dexamethasone was increased. The patient was started on temozolomide IV, but she developed respiratory acidosis/hypercapnia with a CO2 of 115 and was started on a BIPAP, two days later. As a result, a rapid response team was called to transfer the patient to the ICU. The temozolomide was converted to oral dosing via a PEG tube. The patient's family was consulted regarding the patient's status and their options. The patient chose to update her status to do not intubate. The patient was extubated prior to her discharge to a hospice care facility, where she passed away four days later.

Imaging:
MRI of the brain with and without contrast revealed a heterogeneous T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense signal abnormality involving the pontine base and extending into the medulla. There was mildly increased relative cerebral blood flow and blood volume within the enhancing portion of the abnormality, suggesting neovascularity. The pontine component of the lesion also showed no abnormal enhancement or significant hyperperfusion. Mild mass effect on the fourth ventricle was noted. There was no peritumoral edema or significant mass effect. A CT scan of the chest with and without contrast enhancement revealed scattered small ground glass and nodular opacities bilaterally.

Pathology:
The brain biopsy was originally interpreted as a classic medulloblastoma (WHO Grade 4). However, the diagnosis was amended at St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital to small cell glioblastoma (WHO Grade 4). Interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization (iFISH) analysis revealed platelet-derived growth factor receptor A (PDGFRA) amplification. No amplification of MYC, NMYC, or epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) was observed.

Follow-up:
The patient passed away at a hospice care facility four days after discharge.

Approximately one week after admission, the patient's blood pressure stabilized and she was able to respond to verbal commands. However, a head computed tomography showed multiple intracranial hemorrhages associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient's hematomas were later absorbed, and a marked hair loss was observed approximately 2 weeks post-admission. Although the patient's overall condition improved, she experienced multiple organ insufficiencies during her hospital course.

Condition at Discharge:
At discharge, the patient's general condition had improved, and all organ insufficiencies had resolved. The patient worked hard at rehabilitation, and experienced no significant disorders within 6 months after discharge.

Patient: 25-year-old male

Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to multi-fragmentary fractures of the lower third of right tibia and fibula following a motorcycle accident.

Hospital Course:
Upon hospital admission, the patient was alert, coherent, and had no motor deficits. However, forty-eight hours after admission, he developed confusion and agitation, followed by a rapid decline in his level of consciousness that progressed to coma with bilateral extensor posturing. A CT scan revealed multiple and bilateral frontal subcortical hypodense areas without a midline shift. Consequently, a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome (FES) was reached, and the patient received supportive therapy with methylprednisolone (10mg/kg/day) for 3 days.

Two days later, the sedation and analgesia were withheld to assess the patient's neurological status. Subsequently, bilateral and spontaneous extensor posturing was observed with mechanical ventilation asynchrony, tachypnea (46/min), profuse and generalized sweating, arterial hypertension (215/112mmHg), and tachycardia (137/min). These manifestations led to the diagnosis of paroxysmal sympathetic hyperactivity (PSH). Consequently, propranolol (120mg/d) and morphine (3mg) every 4 hours were added to the therapeutic regimen.

On the 8th ICU day, remifentanil and propofol were withdrawn and replaced with dexmedetomidine while propranolol and morphine were maintained at the previous doses. The motor responses improved to the localization of the nociceptive stimulus. The episodes of sympathetic discharge became progressively briefer and less severe and reached no more than 2 per day.

Fourteen days after admission, the patient was extubated. The episodes of PSH were sporadic and less severe, leading to a gradual reduction of propranolol and morphine doses without worsening of sympathetic discharges. Twenty-two days after admission, the fracture was surgically fixed. The post-operative course proceeded without complications.

Discharge Condition:
Upon discharge, the patient had normal motor responses and was able to communicate with his family. The episodes of sympathetic discharges were sporadic and less severe with no significant complications. The patient was discharged home to continue ambulatory rehabilitation.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will follow up with the orthopedic surgeon for scheduled appointments related to the fracture.

Diagnostic Tests and Imaging Studies:
-Head CT scan revealed multiple and bilateral frontal subcortical hypodense areas without a midline shift
-Chest CT scan was normal except for small bilateral basal atelectasis with no evidence of pulmonary embolism
-Transthoracic echocardiography revealed normal ventricles, normal valve function and an absence of patent foramen oval or signs of pulmonary hypertension
-Electroencephalogram revealed diffuse slowing without epileptiform discharges
-Brain MRI revealed multiple small lesions in both cerebral hemispheres that were hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2 and FLAIR, did not show enhancement after gadolinium injection, and were located in the periventricular white matter of both frontoparietal regions

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with fat embolism syndrome (FES) and paroxysmal sympathetic hyperactivity (PSH). The patient received supportive therapy with methylprednisolone (10mg/kg/day) for 3 days, and propranolol (120mg/d) and morphine (3mg) every 4 hours were added to the therapeutic regimen for PSH.

Outcome and Prognosis:
The patient was discharged home to continue ambulatory rehabilitation. The lesions found in the MRI had disappeared after one year, and neuropsychological testing revealed a mild impairment of executive functions with alterations of short and long-term memory. The long-term prognosis for the patient is expected to be favorable with appropriate follow-up care.

The patient did not undergo endovascular treatment due to the presence of a single hemorrhagic metastasis in the right cerebellar hemisphere, contraindicating antiaggregative drugs. The multidisciplinary team made the decision to refrain from the treatment due to the dismal prognosis of the malignancy.

The patient presented at the otorhinolaryngology department with symptoms of nasal obstruction, headaches, sneezing, hyposmia, postnasal drip and coughing. Endoscopic nasal examination showed a bilateral oedematous mass located medially and cranially in the nose, originating anteriorly of the attachment of the concha media. Endoscopic non-aggressive resection was performed and in the follow-up consultation three weeks later the patient was free of symptoms. Endoscopic non-aggressive resection was performed which led to complete symptom resolution and showed no signs of recurrence on follow-up examination four months later.

Principal Diagnosis:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 6-year-old boy with no history of pathological conditions, was admitted to our hospital after suffering an accidental fall from a 3-meter climbing pole. He experienced pain and deformity in the right elbow and wrist joints and was diagnosed with Bado type III Monteggia injury with ipsilateral fracture of the distal radius and ulna.

The patient received manual reduction under nerve block on the day of injury, but due to the difficulty of maintaining the reduction of the radial head, open reduction and percutaneous procedures were performed under general anesthesia. Kirschner wires were inserted for open reduction and fixation of the fractured distal radius and ulna. A long-arm cast was used for external fixation with the elbow in 90° flexion and the forearm in an intermediate position.

After 2 weeks, callus formation at the fractured bone was observed, and therefore, the cast was removed, and range of motion exercises of the elbow and wrist joints were initiated. The Kirschner wires were removed at 6 weeks postsurgery, and pain, range of motion limitation, and lateral instability were not observed in the elbow or wrist joints at 3 months after surgery.

During the 3-year follow-up, radiographs showed a gradual correction in the outward displacement of the radial head. Twenty-one years after surgery, the patient returned to our hospital for another disorder, and radiographs of the previous Monteggia injury were taken. The biocompatibility of the radiocapitellar joint was good, and no malunion was found in the distal radius and ulna.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient reports no spontaneous pain, pain during exercise, tenderness, or range of motion asymmetry, and is currently working as a computer programmer and performs weight training as a hobby without limitations. No further follow-up is planned at this time.
